translated: Those are also mutually dependent on each other, like grass, trees, and wall phenomena, unshakable and inactive. Therefore, because they are devoid of life and so on, they are not living beings.

analyzed: parasparam hetu pratyaya upanibaddha jāḥ anyonye ca acetanāḥ
translated: Mutually dependent on each other as causes and conditions, they are also unconscious.

analyzed: kriyā karma api avabhāsate
translated: Action and karma also appear.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya santatiḥ iyam anāditaḥ pravṛttā
translated: This continuum of causes and conditions has been operating since beginningless [time].

analyzed: yathā ājīvakānām ārhatānām sa cetanāḥ santi
translated: Just as the Jains say that trees are conscious,

analyzed: cala tvāt
translated: because they move,

analyzed: supta tvāt
translated: because they sleep,

analyzed: chinne api utpāda tvāt iti
translated: and because they grow even when cut.

analyzed: yā vyavahāra prajñaptiḥ tādṛśī na asti
translated: Such a designation of conventional knowledge does not exist.

original: bāhyavastuṣu sūryasya candrasya ca sparśavaśena layo vistaraśca anumīyete /
analyzed: bāhya vastuṣu sūryasya candrasya ca sparśa vaśena layaḥ vistaraḥ ca anumīyete
translated: In external objects, the dissolution and expansion of the sun and moon are inferred based on the power of touch.

analyzed: kva teṣām śayana utthānam
translated: Where is their lying down and rising?

original: vāyusañcāravaśād vṛkṣaśākhādikampanānumānāt teṣāṃ gamanāgamanaṃ kuta upalabhyate /
analyzed: vāyu sañcāra vaśāt vṛkṣa śākhā ādi kampana anumānāt teṣām gamana āgamanam kutas upalabhyate
translated: From the inference of the shaking of tree branches and so on based on the power of the movement of the wind, how is their coming and going perceived?

analyzed: arthaḥ usiddhaḥ eva
translated: The object is not established at all.

original: chinne utpāda iti ayam artho'siddha eva iti darśayitum ucyate /
analyzed: chinne utpādaḥ iti ayam arthaḥ usiddhaḥ eva iti darśayitum ucyate
translated: In order to show that the meaning when cut off, it arises is not established, it is said:

analyzed: yadi saḥ upi sa cetanaḥ syat
translated: If that [tree] also had consciousness,

analyzed: kasmāt chedana avasthāyām prāṇa atipatti ityādi duḥkham na anubhavati
translated: why does it not experience suffering such as the sin of killing when it is being cut?

original: anicchādicaryāṃ prārthanādiṃ vā tato'nyatragamanaṃ vā'lpamapi na kurvanti /
analyzed: anicchā ādi caryām prārthanā ādim vā tatas nyatra gamanam vā alpam api na kurvanti
translated: They do not perform even the slightest unwilling action, such as praying, or going elsewhere.

analyzed: chinne utpāda tvāt sa cetana tva abhyupagamaḥ ced
translated: If it is accepted that when cut off, it has consciousness because it arises,

analyzed: tarhi
translated: then when cut off, there is no arising.

analyzed: vyupaśama svabhāvam iti tu karma kleśa rahita tvāt

analyzed: satata sthitam

analyzed: abhayam utpāda vināśa rahitam ca

translated: The meaning of this is that one who sees

analyzed: tasmāt tat eva anuttaram iti uktam

analyzed: dharmakāyaḥ iti dharmakāyaḥ eva dharmakāyaḥ
translated: The Dharma body means the Dharma body itself is the Dharma body.

analyzed: niśādā putravat

analyzed: buddhaḥ iti dharma avabodhāt
translated: Buddha means because of the realization of the Dharma.

original: tathāpi yaḥ pratītyasamutpādaṃ paśyati sa dharmakṛtānuttarabodhyaśaikṣasvabhāvatāṃ paśyati /

analyzed: kasmāt pratītyasamutpādaḥ ucyate iti ced

analyzed: tasmāt uktam

analyzed: sa hetu ādi pada anvitam

analyzed: sa hetukaḥ sa pratyayaḥ ucyate
translated: It is said to have a cause and conditions,

analyzed: na ahetukaḥ na apratyayaḥ

analyzed: bhagavatā pratītyasamutpāda lakṣaṇam saṃkṣepeṇa uktam
translated: The Blessed One has concisely stated the characteristic of dependent origination.

analyzed: etat pratyayasya eva phalam
translated: This is the fruit of that very condition.

analyzed: tasmāt uktam
translated: Therefore it is said:

translated: Whether there is the arising of a Buddha or not, this is the nature of things.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya pravāhaḥ vicchinnaḥ
translated: The stream of causes and conditions is uninterrupted.

analyzed: hetu phalam avicchinnam anyonyam pravartate
translated: The cause and effect continue to occur mutually without interruption.

original: atrāhetuḥ pratikūlahetuḥ vā pravartako nivartako vā ko'pi nāsti /
analyzed: atra ahetuḥ pratikūla hetuḥ vā pravartakaḥ nivartakaḥ vā kaḥ api nā asti
translated: Here there is no cause or unfavorable cause that acts as an instigator or a restrainer.

original: tasmāt tathāgatānāmutpādādvā anutpādād vā dharmato dharmasthitito dharmaniyamataśca eṣa pravāhaḥ / ityuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt tathāgatānām utpādāt vā anutpādāt vā dharmataḥ dharma sthititaḥ dharma niyamataḥ ca eṣa pravāhaḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, whether the Tathāgatas arise or not, this stream is due to the nature of things, the stability of the Dharma, and the regularity of the Dharma. Thus it is said.

original: yadi pratyayarahitena ekenaiva hetunā bhāvā utpadya tiṣṭhanti /
analyzed: yadi pratyaya rahitena ekena eva hetunā bhāvāḥ utpadya tiṣṭhanti
translated: If things arise and endure by a single cause devoid of conditions,

analyzed: yadi pratyayaḥ api hetum an apekṣya kiñcid utpādayitum samarthaḥ ced tadā te sthitāḥ asthitāḥ iti vaktum yujyeta

original: teṣāmutpādaḥ phalodbhavo'pi nāhetor na cāpratyayāt tathāgatānāmutpādo vā'nutpādo vā eṣā dharmatā dharmasthitatā ca āditaḥ pravartete //
analyzed: teṣām utpādaḥ phala udbhavaḥ api na ahetoḥ na ca apratyayāt tathāgatānām utpādaḥ vā anutpādaḥ vā eṣā dharmatā dharma sthitatā ca āditas pravartete
translated: Their arising, the origination of the effect, also does not occur without a cause or without conditions. Thus, the nature of things, the stability of the Dharma, whether it is the arising or non-arising of the Tathāgatas, occurs from the beginning.

original: tadyathā pratītyasamutpādasya dharma etatpratyayatāphalamiti bhagavatā pratītyasamutpādaḥ saṃkṣepeṇa uktaḥ /

translated: For example, the nature of things, which is the effect of these conditions, is the Dharma of dependent origination. The Blessed One has concisely taught dependent origination as this.

analyzed: atra dharmatā tu hetu pratyaya ryoḥ dharmatā
translated: Here, the nature of things is the nature of causes and conditions.

analyzed: dharma sthita tā iti a vipraṇāśa dharma tā
translated: The stability of the Dharma is the nature of non-perishing.

analyzed: dharma niyāma tā iti idaṃpratyaya tā krama niyāma tā
translated: The rule of the Dharma is the rule of the sequence of this conditionality.

original: hetupratyayakramavat pratītyasamutpādasamateti hetvabhāve pratyayāpravṛttiḥ pratyayābhāve ca na hetupravṛttiḥ /
analyzed: hetu pratyaya krama vat pratītyasamutpāda sama tā iti hetu abhāve pratyaya apravṛttiḥ pratyaya abhāve ca na hetu pravṛttiḥ
translated: Dependent origination is equal to the sequence of causes and conditions. When there is no cause, conditions do not occur. And when there are no conditions, causes do not occur.

analyzed: paraspara sāmagryām ca pravṛttiḥ
translated: They occur through mutual combination.

analyzed: ananya tathatā iti anya tā virahita tvāt
translated: Non-otherness suchness means being free from otherness.

analyzed: bhūta tā iti avisaṃvāda tvāt
translated: Reality means non-deception.

analyzed: satya tā iti satya anukūla tvāt
translated: Truth means being in accord with truth.

analyzed: tathatā iti artha anvita tvāt  a viparīta tā iti tu caturvidha viparyaya rahita tvāt
translated: Suchness means being endowed with meaning.🔽Non-erroneousness means being free from the four kinds of error.

analyzed: aviparyaya tā iti anukūla tvāt
translated: Non-reversal means being favorable.

original: evamapi pratītyasamutpādo'yam ityādi hetupratyayadvividhatvād hetupratyayobhayārtha pratītyasamutpādasya kramo'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: evam api pratītyasamutpādaḥ yam ityādi hetu pratyaya dvividha tvāt hetu pratyaya ubhaya artha pratītyasamutpādasya kramaḥ abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Thus, since dependent origination has two kinds of causes and conditions, the sequence of dependent origination should be accepted as having the meaning of both causes and conditions.

analyzed: katamau dvau iti ucyate
translated: What are the two? It is said:

analyzed: hetu upanibandhataḥ pratyaya upanibandhataḥ ca
translated: From the connection with causes and from the connection with conditions.

analyzed: tat ca bāhya ādhyātmika bhedena caturvidhā uvagantavyam
translated: And that should be understood as fourfold, distinguished as external and internal.

analyzed: bāhyaḥ ādhyātmikaḥ ca api dvividhaḥ hetu pratyayaḥ iti uktam
translated: External and internal, twofold, are causes and conditions. Thus it is said.

original: evaṃ bāhyādhyātmikaviśeṣeṇa pṛthag hetupratyayānāṃ lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ kīdṛśa iti cet /
analyzed: evam bāhya ādhyātmika viśeṣeṇa pṛthak hetu pratyayānām lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ kīdṛśaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how the distinction in the characteristics of causes and conditions is made separately by the distinction of external and internal,

analyzed: bāhyaḥ hetuḥ tu bīja ādi iti uktam
translated: it is said that the external cause is the seed and so on.

original: tatra katamo bāhyaḥ sahetukaḥ pratītyasamutpāda iti uktvā tadidam bījādaṅkuraḥ /
analyzed: tatra katamaḥ bāhyaḥ sa hetukaḥ pratītyasamutpādaḥ iti uktvā tat idam bījāt aṅkuraḥ
translated: There, having said What is external dependent origination with causes?, it is said that from that, the sprout is from the seed.

analyzed: aṅkurāt patram
translated: From the sprout, a leaf.

analyzed: patrāt kāṇḍam
translated: From the leaf, a stem.

analyzed: kāṇḍāt na alam
translated: From the stem, a sheath.

original: nālādgaṇḍaḥ gaṇḍād garbham garbhācchūkaḥ puṣpāt phalam ityuktam /
analyzed: nālāt gaṇḍaḥ gaṇḍāt garbham garbhāt śūkaḥ puṣpāt phalam iti uktam
translated: From the sheath, a bud. From the bud, a flower. From the flower, a fruit. This is what is said.

analyzed: pratyayaḥ ṣaḍvidhaḥ mataḥ
translated: The condition is considered to be sixfold.

analyzed: iti tu avasthā tvāt bāhya pratītyasamutpādaḥ iti yojyam
translated: However, this should be connected as external dependent origination because it is a state.

analyzed: ṣaḍvidhaḥ iti tu pṛthivī ādayaḥ ṣaḍvidhāḥ
translated: But sixfold means the six kinds such as earth.

analyzed: tasmāt tu uktam  bīja aṅkura prakāṇḍa ādiḥ phale yadvat pravartate
translated: Therefore, it is said:🔽Just as the sprout, stem, etc. arise from the seed up to the fruit,

original: bīje sati aṅkura kāṇḍādi phala paryantānāṃ prādurbhāvād /
analyzed: bīje sati aṅkura kāṇḍa ādi phala paryantānām prādurbhāvāt

analyzed: aṅkura kāṇḍa ādi phala paryantam na prādurbhavati
translated: When there is no seed, the sprout, stem, etc. up to the fruit do not appear.

original: tatra bījasya naivaṃ bhavati ahamaṅkurādi abhinirvartayāmi iti /
analyzed: tatra bījasya na evam bhavati aham aṅkura ādi abhinirvartayāmi iti
translated: Therein, the seed does not think I produce the sprout, etc.

original: aṅkurasyāpi naivaṃ bhavati ahaṃ bījādinā abhinirvartitaḥ iti /🔽evaṃ yāvat puṣpasya naivaṃ bhavati ahaṃ phalamabhinirvartayāmīti /
analyzed: aṅkurasya api na evam bhavati aham bīja ādinā abhinirvartitaḥ iti  evam yāvat puṣpasya na evam bhavati aham phalam abhinirvartayāmi iti
translated: Nor does the sprout think I am produced from the seed, etc.🔽Similarly, up to the flower does not think I produce the fruit.

original: phalasyāpi naivaṃ bhavati ahaṃ puṣpeṇābhinirvartita iti /
analyzed: phalasya api na evam bhavati aham puṣpeṇa abhinirvartitaḥ iti
translated: Nor does the fruit think I am produced from the flower.

original: atha punarbīje sati aṅkurāditaḥ phalādi paryantaṃ prādurbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha punar bīje sati aṅkura āditaḥ phala ādi paryantam prādurbhāvaḥ
translated: Now, if the seed exists, the sprout appears up to the fruit at the end,

analyzed: asati na bhavati
translated: if it does not exist, it does not occur.

analyzed: evam bāhyasya pratītyasamutpādasya hetu upanibandhaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Thus, the connection of external dependent origination with causes should be seen.

translated: But the conditions are earth, etc., and time, in order.

analyzed: tasmāt eva katham bāhya pratītyasamutpādasya pratyaya upanibandhaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ ityādi uktam
translated: Therefore, it was said how the connection of external dependent origination with conditions should be seen, and so on.

original: bāhyapratītyasamutpādasya pratyayopanibandhāḥ katidhā draṣṭavyā ityuktam ṣaṇṇāṃ dhātūnāṃ samavāyāt /
analyzed: bāhya pratītyasamutpādasya pratyaya upanibandhāḥ katidhā draṣṭavyāḥ iti uktam ṣaṇṇām dhātūnām samavāyāt
translated: It was said how many kinds of connections of conditions should be seen for external dependent origination. From the combination of six elements.

analyzed: katameṣām ṣaṇṇām iti
translated: Which six?

original: pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśartudhātūnāṃ yathākramaṃ samavāyād bāhyapratītyasamutpādasyeti pratyayatā yathākramam /
analyzed: pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa ṛtu dhātūnām yathākramam samavāyāt bāhya pratītyasamutpādasya iti pratyaya tā yathākramam
translated: From the combination of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and season elements, in order, the external dependent origination should be seen as having conditions in order.

analyzed: kramaḥ yathāvat jñātavyaḥ
translated: The order should be understood as it is.

original: eṣām hetupratyayānāṃ katamasya karma katamad iti cet /
analyzed: eṣām hetu pratyayānām katamasya karma katamat iti ced
translated: If it is asked which of these causes and conditions has which function,

analyzed: tasmāt uktam
translated: therefore it was said:

analyzed: dhāraṇam snehanam pākaḥ dhānya vṛddhiḥ anāvṛtiḥ
translated: Holding, moistening, ripening, growth of grain, non-obstruction,

analyzed: pariṇāmaḥ tathā teṣām kāryam tadvat pravartate
translated: and transformation - their function proceeds in that way.

original: tatra pṛthivīdhāturbījasya saṃdhāraṇakṛtyaṃ karotīti bījamaṅkurotpādonmukhamāśrayatvāt kaṭhinatvameva ucyate /
analyzed: tatra pṛthivī dhātuḥ bījasya saṃdhāraṇa kṛtyam karoti iti bījam aṅkura utpāda unmukham āśraya tvāt kaṭhina tvam eva ucyate
translated: Among them, the earth element performs the function of supporting the seed. It is said to be solidity because it is the basis for the seed to be inclined towards producing the sprout.

analyzed: ap dhātuḥ snehayati iti abhiṣyandayati iti bhāṣitaḥ
translated: The water element is said to moisten because it causes to be moistened.

original: tejo dhātuḥ paripācayatīti paripuṣṭayavasare upapadyamāne paraspara sparśeṇoṣṇatā eva paripāka iti ucyate /
analyzed: tejaḥ dhātuḥ paripācayati iti paripuṣṭa yavasare upapadyamāne paraspara sparśeṇa uṣṇa tā eva paripākaḥ iti ucyate
translated: The fire element is said to ripen because heat is ripening when the seed is nourished and the mutual contact causes growth.

analyzed: vāyu dhātuḥ abhinirharati iti vardhana tvāt
translated: The wind element is said to expand because it causes to increase.

original: svāvasthāyāḥ samuddhṛtya bahirā nayanād vāyudhāturbījamabhinirharati vardhayatīti ucyate /
analyzed: sva avasthāyāḥ samuddhṛtya bahirā nayanāt vāyu dhātuḥ bījam abhinirharati vardhayati iti ucyate
translated: The wind element is said to expand the seed by taking it out of its own state and carrying it outside.

analyzed: ākāśa dhātuḥ bīja aṅkura ādīnām anāvaraṇa kṛtyam karoti iti
translated: The space element performs the function of not obstructing the seed, sprout, etc.

analyzed: ākāśa dhātuḥ vighna akaraṇa tvāt anukūla pravṛteḥ bīja aṅkura ādi anāvaraṇa kṛtyam karoti iti ucyate
translated: The space element is said to perform the function of not obstructing the seed, sprout, etc. because it is favorable by not creating obstacles.

original: ṛturapi bījasya pariṇāmanakṛtyaṃ karotīti ṛturapi sarvākāraṃ abhinirharati /
analyzed: ṛtuḥ api bījasya pariṇāmana kṛtyam karoti iti ṛtuḥ api sarvākāram abhinirharati
translated: The season also performs the function of transforming the seed. The season also expands in all aspects.

analyzed: ṛtau yathāvat parivartamāne bīja pariṇāma kṛtyam karoti iti
translated: The season is said to perform the function of transforming the seed when it changes as it should.

analyzed: sarveṣām api a vaikalye prādurbhāvaḥ
translated: When all are complete, there is manifestation.

analyzed: vaikalye tu na prādurbhāvaḥ
translated: But when there is incompleteness, there is no manifestation.

original: tasmādeva uktam /🔽no cet pratyayasāmagrī bīje bhūte'pi nāṅkuraḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt eva uktam  no ced pratyaya sāmagrī bīje bhūte pi nā aṅkuraḥ
translated: Therefore it is said:🔽If not, even with a seed in the elements, there is no sprout without the assemblage of conditions.

analyzed: bīja abhāve tu sati evam pratyaya bhāvaḥ api tādṛśaḥ
translated: But when there is absence of the seed, the conditionality is also like that.

analyzed: tasmāt eva uktam
translated: Therefore it is said:

analyzed: sarva samavāyāt bīje niruddhe tatobhinirhāraḥ syāt
translated: When the seed ceases through the combination of all, then there would be manifestation.

analyzed: hetavaḥ pratyayāḥ tadvat ātma grāha ādi varjitāḥ
translated: Causes and conditions are like that, devoid of grasping of self, etc.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya sāmagryā na naśyet karmaṇaḥ phalam
translated: The fruit of action would not perish through the assemblage of causes and conditions.

original: tatra pṛthivīdhātornaivaṃ bhavati ahaṃ saṃghātakṛtyaṃ karomīti /
analyzed: tatra pṛthivī dhātoḥ na evam bhavati aham saṃghāta kṛtyam karomi iti
translated: Therein, the earth element does not think thus: I perform the function of cohesion.

analyzed: tadvat jale agnau
translated: Similarly, in water, fire,

analyzed: vāyau
translated: air,

analyzed: ākāśe
translated: space,

analyzed: ṛtau ca api na evam bhavati
translated: and in the season, it does not occur thus.

analyzed: ātma ātmīya graha abhāvāt na karma phala prajñapti praṇāśaḥ
translated: Due to the absence of grasping of self and what belongs to self, there is no perishing of the designation of the fruit of action.

analyzed: sarvatra hetu pratyaya vaikalya abhāvāt iti avagantavyam
translated: It should be understood that everywhere there is no lack of causes and conditions.

analyzed: sa uṅkura api iti bīja hetuka tad aṅkura ādīnām
translated: That sprout also - the production of the seed, its sprout, etc., which have the seed as their cause,

original: na svato parato nāpi na dvayoḥ kartṛkālataḥ /
analyzed: na paratas na api na dvayoḥ kartṛ kālataḥ
translated: is not from itself, not from another, not from both, not from time, not from nature, not without cause.

analyzed: īśvara ādi kṛtam na evam svabhāvāt na api ahetutaḥ iti uktam
translated: It is not so, created by God, etc., nor from self, nor without cause.

analyzed: svatas iti hetu pratyaya abhāve svatas utpādaḥ
translated: From self means arising from self without causes and conditions.

analyzed: svabhāva vādinaḥ evam kalpante iti śrūyate
translated: It is heard that those who advocate self-nature imagine thus.

analyzed: bhāvānām svabhāvata satatam atra tiṣṭhati
translated: The self-nature of existents always abides here.

original: atra na kaścidutpadyate na ca kaścin nirudhyate /
analyzed: atra na kaścid utpadyate na ca kaścid nirudhyate
translated: Here, nothing arises and nothing ceases.

analyzed: māyūrasya patra vaicitryam
translated: The variegation of the peacock's feathers.

analyzed: kamala ādiṣu rakta tā
translated: The redness in lotuses, etc.

analyzed: kāṇḍa ādīnām taikṣṇya ādikam kena pūrva nirmitam iti ucyate
translated: By whom was the sharpness, etc., of stalks, etc., previously created? It is said.

analyzed: tasmāt tad mata nirākaraṇāya uktam
translated: Therefore, in order to refute that view, it is said:

analyzed: bhāvānām svatas utpādaḥ na yujyate
translated: The self-arising of existents is not tenable.

analyzed: pūrva adhyavasita tvāt
translated: Because of prior determination.

analyzed: utpattimat tvena abhyupagamyate
translated: It is accepted as having arising.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya tā abhyupagamaḥ
translated: The acceptance of causes and conditions.

original: tasmād vastūnāṃ svabhāvata utpādo na yujyate /
analyzed: tasmāt vastūnām svabhāvataḥ utpādaḥ na yujyate
translated: Therefore, the self-arising of things is not tenable.

analyzed: utpattimat tvāt ghaṭa ādi vat
translated: Because of having arising, like a pot, etc.

original: yasyānusāraṃ bhāvāḥ satataṃ sthitāḥ tadanusāram utpāda kriyā karma sthiti vināśā api na yujyante /
analyzed: yasya anusāram bhāvāḥ satatam sthitāḥ tad anusāram utpāda kriyā karma sthiti vināśāḥ api na yujyante
translated: According to which existents always abide, according to that, arising, action, duration, and destruction are also not tenable.

original: utpāda kriyā karma sthiti vināśā api sākṣād avabhāsante /
analyzed: utpāda kriyā karma sthiti vināśāḥ api sākṣāt avabhāsante
translated: Production, action, and destruction are also directly perceived.

original: tasmād atra doṣasya prasajyamānatvān na svata ityuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt atra doṣasya prasajyamāna tvāt na svatas iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said that it is not from self because a fault is entailed here.

original: bhāvānām svata utpādaścet nityamutpādaprasaṃgaḥ syāt / ākāśavat /
analyzed: bhāvānām svatas utpādaḥ ced nityam utpāda prasaṃgaḥ syāt ākāśa vat
translated: If things were produced from themselves, there would be the fault of production being eternal, like space.

original: kasyacidapi kutrāpi kadāpi utpādo nirodho vā nāstīti cetucyate pratyakṣavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasyacid api kutra api kadāpi utpādaḥ nirodhaḥ vā na asti iti ced ucyate pratyakṣa virodhaḥ
translated: If it is said that there is no production or cessation of anything anywhere at any time, it is said that contradicts perception.

analyzed: evam bhāvānām hetu pratyayāt utpādaḥ bhāsate
translated: Thus, the production of things appears from causes and conditions.

original: tasmāt tāvad bhāvānāṃ na svabhāvata utpādaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tāvat bhāvānām na svabhāvataḥ utpādaḥ
translated: Therefore, things are not produced from their own nature.

analyzed: paratas iti ātmataḥ
translated: From another means from self.

analyzed: pareṣām utpādakaḥ vināśakaḥ ca ātmā asti iti śrūyate
translated: It is heard that there is a self that produces and destroys others.

analyzed: bāhya ābhyantara sarva vastūni tu ātma guṇāḥ
translated: But external and internal things are qualities of the self.

analyzed: ātmā antar karaṇa puruṣaḥ asti
translated: The self is the inner mental person.

original: tathā sati gamana āgamana calana kampana nirākaraṇa manyanā kriyā karmāṇi tatraiva anyatrāpi ca pravartante /
analyzed: tathā sati gamana āgamana calana kampana nirākaraṇa manyanā kriyā karmāṇi tatra eva anyatra api ca pravartante
translated: Thus, going, coming, moving, shaking, denying, conceiving, actions, and deeds occur there and elsewhere as well.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādiḥ ātma guṇaḥ
translated: The eye and so on are qualities of the self.

analyzed: parārtha tvāt
translated: Because they serve another's purpose.

analyzed: śayana ādi aṅga vat iti
translated: Like the parts of a bed, etc.

analyzed: para saṃjñā tu ātmani satī eva ucyate
translated: But the notion of another is spoken of only when there is a self.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādiḥ tad guṇa tvāt
translated: The eye and so on are for the sake of that, because they are its qualities.

analyzed: tad arthaḥ tu parārthaḥ
translated: But that for the sake of which they exist is for the sake of another.

analyzed: yathā śayana ādi paraiḥ upayukta tvāt para artham iti vat para artha tvāt iti
translated: Just as a bed and so on are for the sake of another because they are used by others, so they are for the sake of another because they exist for the sake of another.

original: ayaṃ hetuḥ śayanopamayā na yujyate saṃghātatvāt /
analyzed: ayam hetuḥ śayana upamayā na yujyate saṃghāta tvāt
translated: This reason is not appropriate as a comparison to a bed, because of being a collection.

analyzed: ātmā tva saṃghāta svarūpaḥ
translated: The self is not of the nature of a collection.

original: katham ātmā asaṃghātaḥ san svaśarīrābhāve śayanādīn aṅgasaṃghān svarūpeṇopakartuṃ yujyate /
analyzed: katham ātmā asaṃghātaḥ san sva śarīra abhāve śayana ādīn aṅga saṃghān sva rūpeṇa upakartum yujyate
translated: How can the self, being a non-collection, be appropriate to benefit the collection of limbs such as a bed in its own nature when the body is absent?

analyzed: tasmāt sa hetvarthaḥ usiddhaḥ
translated: Therefore, that meaning of the reason is unestablished.

analyzed: asaṃghātasya para artha niṣpādaka tvāt
translated: Because a non-collection does not accomplish the sake of another.

analyzed: śayana bhedena śayana upamā saṃghātasya parārtha tvam eva sādhayati
translated: The comparison to a bed by the difference in beds only proves that a collection is for the sake of another.

original: ātmanaḥ saṃghātatvād hetupratyayayorutpādopalabdha ātmātmīya iti manyanākārapravṛtteḥ cittamevātmā ityucyate /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ saṃghāta tvāt hetu pratyayayoḥ utpāda upalabdhaḥ ātmā ātmīyaḥ iti manyana ākāra pravṛtteḥ cittam eva ātmā iti ucyate
translated: Because the self is a collection, the arising of causes and conditions is perceived as the self and what belongs to the self. Because it functions with the mode of thinking, the mind itself is called the self.

original: atrāntaḥ karaṇapuruṣaḥ kūrmakeśasvabhāvavad yuktyanumānarahitastu kvacinnāstīti darśayitum bhagavatā bāhyādhyātmikabhāvānāṃ parata utpādo na yujyata ityuktam /
analyzed: atra antar karaṇa puruṣaḥ kūrma keśa svabhāva vat yukti anumāna rahitaḥ tu kvacid na asti iti darśayitum bhagavatā bāhya ādhyātmika bhāvānām paratas utpādaḥ na yujyate iti uktam
translated: Here, in order to show that the internal organ and the person are devoid of logic and inference like the hair of a tortoise, the Blessed One said that the arising of external and internal things from another is not appropriate.

original: yadi bhāvānāṃ svato'pi notpādo na ca parato'pi /
analyzed: yadi bhāvānām svatas api na utpādaḥ na ca paratas api
translated: If things are not produced from themselves, nor from another,

original: tadā bhāvānāṃ dvividha utpāda iti cet /
analyzed: tadā bhāvānām dvividhaḥ utpādaḥ iti ced
translated: then if it is said that the production of things is twofold,

analyzed: tasmāt tad mata niṣedha artham uktam
translated: therefore it is said to refute that view.

original: na dvayoḥ na ca kālata ityuktam /
analyzed: na dvayoḥ na ca kālataḥ iti uktam
translated: It is said: not from both, nor from time.

analyzed: na svatas paratas ca na
translated: Not from itself, not from another.

original: anye tu svaparayoḥ sambandhād bhāvotpādaṃ manyante /
analyzed: anye tu sva parayoḥ sambandhāt bhāva utpādam manyante
translated: But others think that things are produced from the connection of self and other.

analyzed: tasmāt ubhayatas eva vadanti
translated: Therefore they say from both.

original: tathāpi svato'nupalabdhatvāt parataścābhāvāt na dvayoḥ ityuktam /
analyzed: tathā api svatas nupalabdha tvāt paratas ca abhāvāt na dvayoḥ iti uktam
translated: Even so, it is said: not from both, because it is not perceived from itself and because it does not exist from another.

original: hetupratyayātiriktaṃ na svato na parata iti bhagavatā uktam /
analyzed: hetu pratyaya atiriktam na svatas na paratas iti bhagavatā uktam
translated: The Blessed One said: not from itself, not from another, not from both, nor without cause.

analyzed: yadi ubhaya saṃyoge api utpāda vināśau na iṣṭau
translated: If production and destruction are not accepted even when there is a combination of both,

original: tadā paratantreṇa kartrā utpādavināśau bhaviṣyata iti kaiściducyate /
analyzed: tadā paratantreṇa kartrā utpāda vināśau bhaviṣyataḥ iti kaiścid ucyate
translated: then some say that production and destruction will occur through a dependent agent.

original: anye tīrthikāstu karttā nāma kaścid ādyaḥkartā /
analyzed: anye tīrthikāḥ tu karttā nāma kaścid ādyaḥ kartā
translated: But other tīrthikas think that there is some primordial agent named the self,

analyzed: nityaḥ na avacchinnaḥ vyāpakaḥ ca ātmā iti kaścid asti
translated: which is eternal, indivisible, and all-pervading.

original: sa eva bāhyamābhyantarañcedaṃ sarvam utpādayati vināśayatīti manyante /
analyzed: saḥ eva bāhyam ābhyantaram ca idam sarvam utpādayati vināśayati iti manyante
translated: They think that it alone produces and destroys all this external and internal [world].

analyzed: tasmāt tad mata khaṇḍana artham uktam
translated: Therefore, to refute that view, it is said:

analyzed: bhāvānām utpādaḥ sthitiḥ vināśaḥ ca eva na kartṛ adhīnāḥ
translated: The origination, duration, and destruction of things are not dependent on an agent.

original: atha kasyeti cet hetupratyayasambandhād bhāvānāṃ pravṛttirbhāsate /
analyzed: atha kasya iti ced hetu pratyaya sambandhāt bhāvānām pravṛttiḥ bhāsate
translated: If it is asked, Then whose? the activity of things appears from the connection of causes and conditions.

original: kartustu ākāśavan nirvikāratvāt tadadhīnā utpāda sthitivināśāśca naiva yujyante /
analyzed: kartuḥ tu ākāśa vat nirvikāra tvāt tad adhīnāḥ utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ ca na eva yujyante
translated: But for an agent, like space, being changeless, origination, duration, and destruction dependent on that are not tenable.

analyzed: kasmāt iti ced
translated: If it is asked, Why?

original: karttari nirvikāra niṣkriyākāśātmani kriyā karma ca kiñcidapi nāsti /
analyzed: karttari nirvikāra niṣkriya ākāśa ātmani kriyā karma ca kiñcid api na asti
translated: In the changeless, inactive self that is like space, there is no activity or action whatsoever.

original: utpadyamānā bhāvā hetupratyayāpekṣāḥ pravṛtti kramodbhūtā eva bhāsante /
analyzed: utpadyamānāḥ bhāvāḥ hetu pratyaya apekṣāḥ pravṛtti krama udbhūtāḥ eva bhāsante
translated: Things that are originating appear as activity, arising in sequence, dependent on causes and conditions.

original: yadanusāraṃ karttāramapekṣate pravṛttistadanusāraṃ bhāvānām utpāda sthitivināśāśca sadā āsannā bhavanti /🔽karturnityatvād bhāvānām utpādao sthitivināśā yugapad bhaviṣyanti athavā utpāda sthitivināśā na bhaviṣyanti /
analyzed: yad anusāram karttāram apekṣate pravṛttiḥ tad anusāram bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ ca sadā āsannāḥ bhavanti  kartuḥ nitya tvāt bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ yugapad bhaviṣyanti athavā utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ na bhaviṣyanti
translated: According to which [things] require an agent for activity, according to that, the origination, duration, and destruction of things are always near.🔽Because the agent is permanent, the origination, duration, and destruction of things will occur simultaneously, or else origination, duration, and destruction will not occur.

original: nityatvāt kvacidapi kiñcidapi utpādo vā vināśo vā na syāt /
analyzed: nitya tvāt kvacid api kiñcid api utpādaḥ vā vināśaḥ vā na syāt
translated: Because of permanence, there would be no origination or destruction of anything anywhere.

original: hetuṃ pratyayañca apekṣya pravartamānānāṃ bhāvānāmeva kartṛ kriyā hetuphalotpādasamaḥ kramodbhava upalabhyate /
analyzed: hetum pratyayam ca apekṣya pravartamānānām bhāvānām eva kartṛ kriyā hetu phala utpāda samaḥ krama udbhavaḥ upalabhyate
translated: The sequence of arising is observed only for things that occur in dependence on causes and conditions, where the agent, action, cause, and effect are produced in sequence.

original: anutpannā kāśotpalādīnāntu utpāda sthiti vināśā na yujyante /
analyzed: anutpannā kāśa utpala ādīnāntu utpāda sthiti vināśā na yujyante
translated: But for non-arisen things like sky-lotuses, arising, enduring, and ceasing are not tenable.

original: avikārahetubhiḥ parasparamāśritya pravartamānaiḥ utpādaniyamo na yujyate /
analyzed: avikāra hetubhiḥ parasparam āśritya pravartamānaiḥ utpāda niyamaḥ na yujyate
translated: The restriction of arising is not tenable for things that occur in mutual dependence, with unchanging causes.

original: nityabhāvādanityo hi samutpādo na yujyate /🔽hetutastvavikāratvāt samasyaivodbhave sati /
analyzed: nitya bhāvāt anityaḥ hi samutpādaḥ na yujyate  hetutaḥ tu avikāra tvāt samasyā eva udbhave sati
translated: Because of permanence, impermanence is not tenable for arising.🔽If the effect arises simultaneously with the cause, due to the cause, and because of unchangingness,

original: hetau phale ca saṃbhinne'vikārastu kathaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: hetau phale ca saṃbhinne vikāraḥ tu katham bhavet
translated: how could there be unchangingness when the effect is connected to the cause?

analyzed: hetau vikārasya api bhūta tvāt tad asādṛśya pakṣaḥ naṣṭaḥ
translated: Because even the change of the cause has already occurred, the position of dissimilarity is lost.

original: kriyānanvitavandhyāputrātmani kasyāścit kriyāyāḥ karmaṇo vā niyatena ayuktatvād bhagavaddharmeṣu avisaṃvāditvād bhāvotpādakriyā karttāraṃ nāpekṣate /
analyzed: kriyā ananvita vandhyā putra ātmani kasyāścid kriyāyāḥ karmaṇaḥ vā niyatena ayukta tvāt bhagavat dharmeṣu avisaṃvādi tvāt bhāva utpāda kriyā karttāram nā apekṣate
translated: Because it is not tenable that any action or object is restricted to something that is not connected with action, like the son of a barren woman, therefore the action of producing things does not depend on an agent, because of non-contradiction with the Lord's attributes.

original: kintu sati hetupratyayasaṅgrahe bhāvānāmutpādavināśau yujyeta ityuktam /
analyzed: kintu sati hetu pratyaya saṅgrahe bhāvānām utpāda vināśau yujyeta iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the arising and ceasing of things is tenable only when there is a collection of causes and conditions.

analyzed: yadi evam atra bhāva utpāda sthiti anyathā bhāva tā ādiḥ abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: If so, here the arising, duration, and transformation of entities must be accepted.

analyzed: bhāva utpāda sthitīnām tu jñātavyaḥ hetuḥ īśvaraḥ
translated: But the cause of the arising and duration of entities should be known as God.

analyzed: anyeṣām vipratipattiḥ yathāvat taiḥ hi bhāṣyate
translated: The views of others are stated as they are, according to their true nature.

original: anyaiḥ sattvabhājanalokayorutpāda sthiti vināśāstu īśvarakṛtapraṇāśā avagamyante /
analyzed: anyaiḥ sattva bhājana lokayoḥ utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ tu īśvara kṛta praṇāśāḥ avagamyante
translated: Others understand that the creation, duration, and destruction of the world of beings and inanimate objects are due to God's will.

original: tadīśvarecchāvaśāt kāya bhūmitraya kartrādisaṃbhavaḥ syāditi śrūyate /
analyzed: tad īśvara icchā vaśāt kāya bhūmi traya kartṛ ādi saṃbhavaḥ syāt iti śrūyate
translated: It is heard that the existence of the three realms, the creator, and so on, is possible by the power of God's will.

original: anye tasyaiva cittotpādamātreṇa naraka preta tiryak deva manuṣyadayāśca sattvāḥ jvara viṣa vyādhi strī puruṣa napuṃsaka sukṛtarūpa vikṛtarūpa dasyu jihma caurāḥ kāmamithyācāra prāṇātipāta mṛṣāvāda madyapāna dyūtapraveśa pratyanta śabara ḍombī nirdaya krūra pāruṣyavāda brahmaghāta mātṛpitṛghātaka vyādhādayaḥ /
analyzed: anye tasya eva citta utpāda mātreṇa naraka preta tiryak deva manuṣya dayāḥ ca sattvāḥ jvara viṣa vyādhi strī puruṣa napuṃsaka sukṛta rūpa vikṛta rūpa dasyu jihma caurāḥ kāma mithyā ācāra prāṇātipāta mṛṣāvāda madya pāna dyūtapraveśa pratyanta śabara ḍombī nirdaya krūra pāruṣya vāda brahma ghāta mātṛ pitṛ ghātaka vyādha ādayaḥ
translated: Others say that by the mere arising of His mind, beings in hell, ghosts, animals, gods, humans, and other realms, with various forms of good and bad appearance, such as men, women, eunuchs, with good and bad forms, robbers, crooked, thieves, those who engage in sexual misconduct, killing, lying, drinking alcohol, gambling, those who enter remote areas, Shabaras, Domis, the merciless, cruel, harsh-speaking, killers of Brahmins, mothers, fathers, and hunters, and so on,🔽Yakshas, Rakshasas, Dakinis, and all others who harm others,

analyzed: yakṣa rākṣasa ḍākinī ādayaḥ sarve para ghātakāḥ
translated: are created.

original: sukha duḥkhādayaḥ svargo vimokṣaśca tāni sarvāṇi cittotpādamātreṇoddhṛtānīti vadanti /
analyzed: sukha duḥkha ādayaḥ svargaḥ vimokṣaḥ ca tāni sarvāṇi citta utpāda mātreṇa uddhṛtāni iti vadanti
translated: They say that all these, such as pleasure, pain, heaven, and liberation, are attained merely by generating the mind [of enlightenment].

analyzed: īśvara kartṛ tva vādinaḥ uti sukumāra prajñāḥ eva
translated: Those who advocate the doctrine of God as the creator are indeed of very tender intellect.

analyzed: ati manda prajñāḥ eva
translated: They are indeed of very dull intellect.

original: gatānugatikāścaiva yuktiviśeṣarahite tasmin gauravapravaṇatvāt pūrvottaraviruddhaṃ bālayuvakacāṇḍālavadayathārtha pratyakṣādiviruddhaṃ /
analyzed: gatānugatikāḥ ca eva yukti viśeṣa rahite tasmin gaurava pravaṇa tvāt pūrva uttara viruddham bāla yuvaka cāṇḍāla vat ayathārtha pratyakṣa ādi viruddham
translated: And they are mere followers, for they are inclined to reverence that [God] which lacks any special reasoning. It is contrary to the earlier and later [teachings], like a child and a youth, and contrary to the true [teachings] such as perception.

analyzed: dāna vinaya saṃyama eṣṭa aniṣṭa phalam
translated: [It is contrary to] the fruits of giving, discipline, restraint, and what is desired and undesired.

analyzed: sukṛta duṣkṛta karma  gamya agamyam
translated: [It is contrary to] good and bad actions.🔽[It is contrary to] what is to be approached and what is not to be approached.

analyzed: bhakṣya abhakṣyam
translated: [It is contrary to] what is to be eaten and what is not to be eaten.

analyzed: svarga apavarga ādi phala viruddham
translated: [It is contrary to] the fruits such as heaven and liberation.

original: yuktyāgamādiviruddhaṃ ca vāṅmātreṇa pakṣīkṛtya nijājñānapaṭalena netrācchādanatvād asamarthatvāt paśubhūtāstu paśubhyo'pyatichudratarāḥ paśavaḥ
analyzed: yukti āgama ādi viruddham ca vāc mātreṇa pakṣīkṛtya nija ajñāna paṭalena netra ācchādana tvāt asamartha tvāt paśu bhūtāḥ tu paśubhyaḥ api ati chudratarāḥ paśavaḥ
translated: And it is contrary to reasoning, scriptures, and so on. Having made it a thesis merely by words, because of covering the eyes with the veil of one's own ignorance, they are incapable. They are like animals, even more inferior than animals.

analyzed: nigūḍha vandhyā putra svabhāvam paśupatim āśritya
translated: Relying on Pashupati, whose nature is like the son of a hidden barren woman.

analyzed: janma sthiti vināśānām hetutāṃsi api tu uccatām
translated: The causes of birth, existence, and destruction, though, attain greatness.

original: utpāde sthitau ca sahetuka evābhyupagamyamāne sati nityavādabhaṅgatvād vādotsargaḥ /
analyzed: utpāde sthitau ca sa hetuke eva abhyupagamyamāne sati nitya vāda bhaṅga tvāt vāda utsargaḥ
translated: When production and persistence are accepted as having a cause, the doctrine is abandoned because it contradicts the doctrine of permanence.

analyzed: viparīta siddha tvāt īśvarasya ahetu tvam eva sidhyati
translated: Because of the opposite being established, God is established as having no cause.

original: icchāmātreṇa utpāde sati yugapadeva sampūrṇajagata utpādasthitivināśāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: icchā mātreṇa utpāde sati yugapad eva sampūrṇa jagataḥ utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ syuḥ
translated: If production were by mere will, then the production, persistence, and destruction of the entire world would occur simultaneously.

analyzed: tasmāt api asiddhārtha tā eva syāt
translated: Therefore, it would also be unestablished.

analyzed: sarveṣām nitya utpāda prasaṅga tvāt
translated: Because it would follow that everything would be produced constantly.

original: duḥkha kuhanā jihma aśuci akṛtajñatādyuddharaṇānāṃ tu prayojanaviśeṣābhāvācca asiddhārthatā /
analyzed: duḥkha kuhanā jihma aśuci akṛtajña tā ādi uddharaṇānām tu prayojana viśeṣa abhāvāt ca asiddhārtha tā
translated: And because there is no specific purpose for removing suffering, deceit, impurity, ingratitude, and so on, it is unestablished.

analyzed: tad uddharaṇa āyāsaḥ niṣphalaḥ
translated: The effort to remove them is fruitless.

analyzed: prayojana abhāve hi kalpanā pūrvaṅgamānām pravṛttiḥ nā asti
translated: For those who act with prior imagination do not engage in action in the absence of a purpose.

analyzed: prayojana avyāpteḥ
translated: Because it is not encompassed by the purpose.

analyzed: tad prayojana vat vyāvṛttau kalpanā pūrvaṅgamānām pravṛtteḥ api nivṛtteḥ asiddhārtha tā asti
translated: When that which is like the purpose is excluded, even the engagement of those who act with prior imagination ceases, so it is unestablished.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya vaikalye krama utpāda vināśau
translated: In the absence of causes and conditions, sequential production and destruction

analyzed: pratyakṣa tayā bhāsete
translated: appear as directly perceptible.

analyzed: avaikalye ca anutpādaḥ
translated: And in the presence of completeness, there is no production.

analyzed: sattva bhājana lokayoḥ utpadyamāna sukha duḥkha ādīnām sthiti vināśau kramaśas upalabhyete
translated: The persistence and destruction of the happiness, suffering, etc. that arise in the world of beings and inanimate objects are observed in sequence.

analyzed: tasmāt naḥ īśvaraḥ hetuḥ
translated: Therefore, God is not the cause.

original: kasyacidapi bhāvasya utpāda sthiti vināśā na yujyante /
analyzed: kasyacid api bhāvasya utpāda sthiti vināśā na yujyante
translated: The arising, persistence, and destruction of any existent thing are not tenable.

original: tasmādapi pratyakṣavirodho'siddhārtha eva /🔽nānyat pratyakṣato garīyaḥ pramāṇamiti sarvavādiprasiddham /
analyzed: tasmāt api pratyakṣa virodhaḥ usiddhārthaḥ eva  na anyat pratyakṣataḥ garīyaḥ pramāṇam iti sarva vādi prasiddham
translated: Therefore, even the unestablished meaning is contradicted by perception.🔽It is well-known to all proponents that there is no means of valid cognition greater than perception.

analyzed: na ekāntā ṛthakriyā
translated: There is no single-pointed purposeful action.

analyzed: dayā pratāpa abhāve
translated: In the absence of compassion and power,

original: gambhīryaguṇa darśana caryā cintanādi na yujyate /
analyzed: gambhīrya guṇa darśana caryā cintana ādi na yujyate
translated: the contemplation, practice, etc. of the qualities of profundity are not tenable.

original: ekāntakriyāyuktā yuktayorgāmbhīryaguṇasya rūpādervā ālambana cintanasyaiva ayuktatvāt /
analyzed: ekānta kriyā yuktā yuktayoḥ gāmbhīrya guṇasya rūpa ādeḥ vā ālambana cintanasya eva ayukta tvāt
translated: Because the contemplation of the object itself is not tenable for the two who are engaged in single-pointed purposeful action, or for the qualities of profundity, or for form, etc.

analyzed: tat tu pratikūlam
translated: But that is contrary.

original: hetāvasati sarvatra pratyaya eva kathaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: hetau asati sarvatra pratyayaḥ eva katham bhavet
translated: When there is no cause, how can there be a condition everywhere?

analyzed: ahetau kāraka abhāvāt katham īṣṭe maheśvaraḥ
translated: How is the great Lord accepted when there is no cause, due to the absence of an agent?

original: bhāvakartā maheśaścet so'pi kartā na manyate /
analyzed: bhāva kartā maheśaḥ ced saḥ upi kartā na manyate
translated: If the great Lord is the maker of existence, he is also not accepted as the maker.

original: pitrabhāve sutotpattiḥ sā neṣṭā dṛśyate na ca /
analyzed: pitṛ abhāve suta utpattiḥ sā na iṣṭā dṛśyate na ca
translated: The birth of a son in the absence of a father is not accepted, and is not seen.

analyzed: hetu nisyanda sādṛśyam manyante yukti vādinaḥ
translated: Those who speak logically consider the outflow to be similar to the cause.

analyzed: nityāt nitya phalam yuktam anityāt ca api anityakam
translated: The eternal and non-eternal are logically connected with eternal and non-eternal fruits.

analyzed: śāli bījāt phalam tasmāt aṅkura utpādaḥ īkṣyate
translated: The fruit from a rice seed is seen to be the production of a sprout.

original: tathā maheśvare nitye bhāvānāṃ syāt sadodbhavaḥ /🔽yathāgnirdāhayetsarvaṃ tathācedīśvaro mataḥ /
analyzed: tathā maheśvare nitye bhāvānām syāt sadā udbhavaḥ  yathā agniḥ dāhayet sarvam tathā ced īśvaraḥ mataḥ
translated: Similarly, if Mahesvara is eternal, the origination of things would always be.🔽If it is thought that Mahesvara is like fire, which burns everything,

analyzed: agni hetuḥ tathā anyaḥ agniḥ īśvare na asti hetukam
translated: then just as one fire is the cause of another fire, there is no cause for Mahesvara.

analyzed: krama pravṛtta jvālābhiḥ sarva dāhaḥ api manyate
translated: Even the burning of everything is thought to be by the flames occurring in sequence.

analyzed: īśvarasya avikāri tvāt agni vat tvam na yujyate
translated: Because Mahesvara is unchanging, it is not logical for him to be like fire.

original: tasmādīśvarakartṛtvābhyupagame bahudoṣasaṃbhavād bhagavatā bhāvānām utpādaḥ īśvarakṛto na yujyate ityuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt īśvara kartṛ tva abhyupagame bahu doṣa saṃbhavāt bhagavatā bhāvānām utpādaḥ īśvara kṛtaḥ na yujyate iti uktam
translated: Therefore, because many faults would arise if one accepts Mahesvara as the creator, the Blessed One said that the origination of things cannot be the work of Mahesvara.

original: pare tu sarvaṃ kālena vivartitaṃ manyante /
analyzed: pare tu sarvam kālena vivartitam manyante
translated: Others, however, think that everything is transformed by time.

analyzed: taiḥ evam ucyate  sthitiḥ bhāvān samutpādya kālena eva vivartyate
translated: They say this:🔽Time, having produced things, transforms them again.

analyzed: bhāva utpāda sthitī ca api kālena eva vivartite
translated: The origination and duration of things are also transformed by time itself.

analyzed: tat evam ucyate
translated: This is said:

analyzed: atra kālaḥ iti kim nāma
translated: Here, what is this so-called time?

analyzed: nityaḥ vā anityaḥ vā
translated: Is it eternal or non-eternal?

analyzed: puruṣaḥ strī napuṃsaka svabhāvaḥ vā
translated: Is it of the nature of a male, female, or neuter?

analyzed: devaḥ piśācaḥ vā
translated: Is it a god or a demon?

analyzed: mūrtaḥ a mūrtaḥ vā
translated: Whether embodied or formless.

analyzed: sakriyaḥ niṣkriyaḥ vā
translated: Whether active or inactive.

original: sa nityaścettadā tatra kriyāpekṣā na yujyate /
analyzed: sa nityaḥ ced tadā tatra kriyā apekṣā na yujyate
translated: If it is eternal, then the dependence on action there is not proper.

analyzed: utpādaḥ ced sakṛt saḥ api viruddha tvāt na manyate
translated: If it is production, that also is not accepted because of contradiction.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya yogataḥ
translated: In non-eternality, due to the connection with cause and conditions,

analyzed: yadi pum strī napuṃsa ādi yat kiñcid syāt virudhyate
translated: if it is anything like male, female, neuter, etc., it is contradicted.

analyzed: dehi adehi kriyā ādau ca pāraspara viruddha tā
translated: And in the case of embodied and disembodied action, etc., there is mutual contradiction.

analyzed: nitya tve nirvikāra tvāt kriyā karma virudhyate
translated: In eternality, due to immutability, action and object are contradicted.

original: evaṃ kālavādināṃ kālavaśena bhāvānāmutpāda sthiti vināśābhyu pagamasyāpi ayuktatvāt tadapyasamañjasameva /
analyzed: evam kāla vādinām kāla vaśena bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśa abhyu pagamasya api ayukta tvāt tat api asamañjasam eva
translated: Thus, for those who assert time, the acceptance of the production, duration, and destruction of things by the power of time is also improper, so that is also incoherent.

original: sūryacandra nakṣatra parva vatsarādi bāhyābhyantarabhāvānāṃ gatagamyasvabhāvatvāt kālākhyayā bhāvānāmutpāda sthiti vināśāstu kālapariṇāmatvena na yujyante /
analyzed: sūrya candra nakṣatra parva vatsara ādi bāhya abhyantara bhāvānām gata gamya svabhāva tvāt kāla ākhyayā bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ tu kāla pariṇāma tvena na yujyante
translated: Because external and internal things have the nature of being gone and being gone over, like the sun, moon, stars, Parva, year, etc., the production, duration, and destruction of things are not proper as the transformation of time, called time.

original: anyacca / svabhāvavādina āntarabāhyān sarvabhāvān svabhāvodbhavān manyante /
analyzed: anyat ca svabhāva vādinaḥ āntara bāhyān sarva bhāvān svabhāva udbhavān manyante
translated: Moreover, those who assert inherent nature consider all internal and external things to arise from inherent nature.🔽The inherent nature of things is

analyzed: bhāvānām svabhāvaḥ eva
translated: The nature of things is just that.

original: kasyacidbhāvasya utpādasya vināśasya vā kaścidapi heturnāsti /🔽khara snigdha uṣṇa laghutva ślakṣṇa tīkṣṇāni svabhāva eva /
analyzed: kasyacid bhāvasya utpādasya vināśasya vā kaścid api hetuḥ na asti  khara snigdha uṣṇa laghu tva ślakṣṇa tīkṣṇāni svabhāva eva
translated: For no cause whatsoever exists for the production or destruction of any entity.🔽Roughness, smoothness, heat, lightness, softness, and sharpness are simply inherent natures.

original: madhura amla lavaṇa kaṭukāni asattvabhedā eva /
analyzed: madhura amla lavaṇa kaṭukāni asattva bhedāḥ eva
translated: Sweetness, sourness, saltiness, and bitterness are simply distinctions of non-existence.

analyzed: deva mānuṣa tiryañcaḥ rāja brahma ku jātayaḥ
translated: Gods, humans, animals, kings, Brahmins, and low castes,

original: sukṛtaṃ duṣkṛtaṃ cāpi sukhaṃ duḥkhaṃ sadā sthitam /
analyzed: sukṛtam duṣkṛtam ca api sukham duḥkham sadā sthitam
translated: Good deeds and bad deeds, happiness and suffering always exist.

analyzed: svabhāva vaimatyā tebhyaḥ bhrānta cittebhyaḥ evam vaktavyam
translated: For those with deluded minds, this should be said:

analyzed: svabhāve vikṛte dṛṣṭe pratyakṣa ādi viruddha tā
translated: When a change in nature is seen, it contradicts perception and other [means of valid cognition].

original: vikāro vartate yatra nirvikāraḥ kathaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: vikāraḥ vartate yatra nirvikāraḥ katham bhavet
translated: Where change occurs, how can it be without change?

analyzed: vyakti aneka prabhedāt ca janma nāśaḥ ca bhāsate
translated: And because manifestation has many divisions, birth and destruction appear.

analyzed: jāteḥ vināśa sambandhāt nirvikāraḥ katham bhavet
translated: How can it be without change due to the connection of birth and destruction with manifestation?

analyzed: svabhāve nirvikāra tvāt puruṣa ādau nirarthake
translated: Because nature is unchanging, in a useless person and so on,

original: kule rājani kṣetrādau tatphalaṃ cāpi bhāsate /
analyzed: kule rājani kṣetra ādau tad phalam ca api bhāsate
translated: The result of that [nature] also appears in a family, king, field, and so on.

original: svabhāve vikṛte jāte nityavādī tu bhraṃsate /
analyzed: svabhāve vikṛte jāte nitya vādī tu bhraṃsate
translated: When a change in nature occurs, the proponent of permanence falls.

analyzed: mārgaḥ ūyam yujyate tasmāt hetu pratyaya vādinām
translated: Therefore, this path is appropriate for those who speak of causes and conditions.

original: evaṃ svabhāvavādiṣvapi parasparavirodhatvād utpāda sthiti vināśānāṃ svabhāvād udbhavo na yujyata ityuktam /
analyzed: evam svabhāva vādiṣu api paraspara virodha tvāt utpāda sthiti vināśānām svabhāvāt udbhavaḥ na yujyate iti uktam
translated: Thus, even in the case of those who maintain that [existence, duration, and cessation] are inherent in things, because of mutual contradiction, it is said that the arising of existence, duration, and cessation from their own nature is not tenable.

original: atha bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśā ahetuto bhavanti ityapare'hetuvādino hetuṃ vinaiva kevalam bhāvānāmutpāda nirodhau kalpayanti /
analyzed: atha bhāvānām utpāda sthiti vināśāḥ ahetutaḥ bhavanti iti apare hetuvādinaḥ hetum vinā eva kevalam bhāvānām utpāda nirodhau kalpayanti
translated: If others maintain that the arising, duration, and cessation of things occur without a cause, they imagine the arising and cessation of things without any cause at all.

analyzed: ahetuvādaḥ abhyapagamyeta ced
translated: If the doctrine of causelessness were accepted,

original: hetoḥ aniścitatvāt kṛtapraṇāśa akṛtābhyāgama anavasthāśca bhaviṣyanti /
analyzed: hetoḥ aniścita tvāt kṛta praṇāśa akṛta abhyāgama anavasthāḥ ca bhaviṣyanti
translated: because the cause would be uncertain, what has been done would be lost, what has not been done would be encountered, and there would be an infinite regress.

original: sukṛta duṣkṛtādi pitṛ putra brāhmaṇa rājanya vaiśya śūdra śvapacādi śucyaśuci gamyāgamya bhakṣyābhakṣya devapiśācādi dāna vinaya saṃyama japa tapasyā upavāsa niścaya yāgajñānājñāna hetvaniścayāt parasparabhedanirṇaya vyavasthāpi na saṃbhavati tasmāttasyaiva doṣasya prasajyamānatvād ahetuvādo'pi lokādi viruddhatvād asiddha eva /
analyzed: sukṛta duṣkṛta ādi pitṛ putra brāhmaṇa rājanya vaiśya śūdra śvapaca ādi śuci aśuci gamya agamya bhakṣya abhakṣya deva piśāca ādi dāna vinaya saṃyama japa tapasyā upavāsa niścaya yāga jñāna ajñāna hetu aniścayāt paraspara bheda nirṇaya vyavasthā api na saṃbhavati tasmāt tasya eva doṣasya prasajyamāna tvāt ahetuvādaḥ api loka ādi viruddha tvāt asiddhaḥ eva
translated: Because the cause is uncertain, the determination and establishment of the distinction between good and bad actions, father and son, brahmin and kṣatriya, vaiśya and śūdra, cāṇḍāla and so on, pure and impure, permissible and impermissible, edible and inedible, god and demon, giving, discipline, restraint, recitation, austerity, fasting, resolve, sacrifice, knowledge, ignorance, and so on, are also not possible. Therefore, because that same fault would ensue, the doctrine of causelessness is also unestablished because it contradicts the world and so on.

original: ye cānye pradhāna paramāṇvādyahetu pratikūlahetuvādādayaste'pi tenaiva niṣedhi tavyāḥ / tasmān /
analyzed: ye ca anye tena eva niṣedhi tasmāt
translated: And the others, such as the theories of Primordial Matter, Atoms, etc., and the theories of non-causation and contrary causation, should also be refuted by the same. Therefore,

original: na svataḥ parato nāpi na dvayoḥ kartṛkālataḥ /
analyzed: na svatas paratas na api na dvayoḥ kartṛ kālataḥ
translated: It is not from itself, nor from another, nor from both, nor without cause.

analyzed: īśvara ādi kṛtam nā eva svabhāvāt na api ahetutaḥ iti uktam
translated: It is not created by God, etc., nor by inherent nature, nor without cause. Thus it is said.

analyzed: hetu pratyayayoḥ vṛttiḥ rbhāsate na ādi kālataḥ
translated: The functioning of causes and conditions appears from beginningless time.

original: iti tu anādi kālataḥ prapañca vāsanābījasya avicchinna nadīstrotaḥ pravāhavad anupravṛtteḥ
analyzed: iti tu anādi kālataḥ prapañca vāsanā bījasya avicchinna nadī strotaḥ pravāha vat anupravṛtteḥ
translated: However, it is said that the functioning of causes and conditions appears from beginningless time because the seed of the latent tendencies of the world has continued like an uninterrupted river current.

analyzed: hetu pratyayayoḥ vṛttiḥ bhāsate ādi kālataḥ iti uktam
translated: The functioning of causes and conditions appears from beginningless time.

original: tasmādeva sūtre atha punaḥ pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśartudhātusamavāyād bīje nirudhyamāne aṅkurasyābhinirvṛttirbhavati ityuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt eva sūtre atha punar pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa ṛtu dhātu samavāyāt bīje nirudhyamāne aṅkurasya abhinirvṛttiḥ bhavati iti uktam
translated: Therefore, in that sūtra, it is said: Moreover, when the seed is ceasing due to the combination of the elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and season, the manifestation of the sprout occurs.

original: 'atha punaḥ' iti tu abhāvādudbhava sva para dvaya īśvarādi rahita bīja pṛthivyādi sāmagryā eva aṅkurādi utpadyata iti uktam /
analyzed: atha punar iti tu abhāvāt udbhava sva para dvaya īśvara ādi rahita bīja pṛthivī ādi sāmagryā eva aṅkura ādi utpadyate iti uktam
translated: Moreover means that it is said that the sprout, etc. arise only from the assemblage of seeds, earth, etc., devoid of the two extremes of existence from self and non-existence from another, God, etc.

analyzed: pañcabhiḥ hetubhiḥ bāhyaḥ pratītya utpādaḥ iṣyate iti
translated: The external dependent origination is accepted due to five causes.

analyzed: pañcabhiḥ hetubhiḥ iti tu hetu pañcakaiḥ iti  bāhyasya iti bīja ādeḥ
translated: Of the external means of seed and so on.

analyzed: pratītya utpādaḥ iti pratītyam
translated: Dependent origination means dependent arising.

original: śāśvatato na cocchedān na saṅkrānteḥ parīttataḥ /
analyzed: śāśvatataḥ na ca ucchedāt na saṅkrānteḥ parīttataḥ
translated: Not from permanence, not from annihilation, not from transference, not from a small cause,

analyzed: iti uktam
translated: The attainment of a great fruit from a small cause, and the arising of a similar effect from a similar cause. This has been stated.

analyzed: śāśvatataḥ naḥ iti yasmāt anyat bījam
translated: Not from permanence means because the seed is one thing,

analyzed: anya oṅkuraḥ  na ca ye eva aṅkurāḥ tat eva bījam
translated: the sprout is another.🔽And the sprout is not the seed itself.

analyzed: bījam eva api na aṅkuraḥ  aniruddhāt bījāt api aṅkuraḥ na utpadyate
translated: The seed is not the sprout either.🔽The sprout does not arise from an unceased seed.

analyzed: na ca niruddhāt
translated: Nor does it arise from a ceased seed.

analyzed: tathā api bīja nirodhe aṅkuraḥ utpadyate
translated: Nevertheless, the sprout arises from the cessation of the seed.

analyzed: tasmāt na
translated: Therefore, not from permanence.

original: na cocchedāditi na ca pūrvaniruddhādbījādaṅkuro niṣpadyate nācāpyaniruddhād /
analyzed: na ca ucchedāt iti na ca pūrva niruddhāt bījāt aṅkuraḥ niṣpadyate
translated: Not from annihilation means the sprout does not arise from a seed that has already ceased, nor from a seed that has not yet ceased.

original: api tu bījād niruddhāt tasminneva samaye'ṅkuro utpadyate /
analyzed: api tu bījāt niruddhāt tasmin eva samaye iṅkuraḥ utpadyate
translated: Rather, the sprout arises at the very same time as the seed ceases.

analyzed: atas na ucchedataḥ
translated: Therefore, not from annihilation.

original: na saṃkrāntitaḥ iti tu bījāṅkurau tu asadṛśau eva /
analyzed: na saṃkrāntitaḥ iti tu bījāṅkurau tu asadṛśau eva
translated: Not from transference means the seed and sprout are not similar.

analyzed: tasmāt na saṃkrāntitaḥ
translated: Therefore, not from transference.

original: parīttataḥ hetoriti parīttabījavapanān mahāphalāvāptiriti tatparītta hetorbahuphalābhinirvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: parīttataḥ hetoḥ iti parītta bīja vapanāt mahā phala avāptiḥ iti tad parītta hetoḥ bahu phala abhinirvṛttiḥ
translated: From a small cause means from planting a small seed, one obtains a great fruit. Thus, from a small cause, a great fruit is produced.

analyzed: parīttāt mahā phala abhi nirvṛtti tvāt
translated: Because a great fruit is produced from a small cause.

analyzed: tasmāt parītta hetoḥ mahā phala abhinirvṛtiḥ
translated: Therefore, from a small cause, a great fruit is produced.

original: sadṛśānuprabodhād iti tu yādṛśaṃ bījamupyate tādṛśameva phalābhinirvṛtiriti /
analyzed: sadṛśa anuprabodhāt iti tu yādṛśam bījam upyate tādṛśam eva phala abhinirvṛtiḥ iti
translated: From the arousal of a similar kind means that whatever kind of seed is sown, that very kind of fruit is produced.

analyzed: atas tad sadṛśa anuprabandhaḥ

analyzed: sadṛśa a phala abhinirvṛttiḥ  bīja aṅkurayoḥ bhinna tvāt bījam nityam na vartate

analyzed: yatas ca ucchedataḥ nā asti bīje sati tathā aṅkuraḥ
translated: And because there is no annihilation, when there is a seed, the sprout is like that.

analyzed: bīja sādṛśya siddha tvāt tat bhinnam na ca iṣyate
translated: Because the similarity to the seed is established, it is not accepted as different.

analyzed: aṅkurasya phala ādīnām saṅkrāntiḥ ca aṅkurasya na
translated: And there is no transference of the sprout to the fruit, etc.

analyzed: eka bījam parītta aṇoḥ bīja tvena eva sambhavet
translated: A single seed would be possible only as a seed for a small plant.

analyzed: tasmāt hetoḥ jāyate hi mahat phalam
translated: Therefore, from a small cause, a great fruit is produced.

original: upte śālyādi bīje hi śyāmākādiphalaṃ na hi /
analyzed: upte śāli ādi bīje hi śyāmāka ādi phalam na hi

analyzed: tasmāt eva
translated: Therefore, from that very

analyzed: aṅkuraḥ bīja vat na iṣṭaḥ nirhetuḥ na uṅkura udbhavaḥ
translated: The sprout is not accepted as similar to the seed, and the arising of the sprout without a cause is not accepted.

analyzed: samaḥ nirodhaḥ utpādaḥ iti uktam

analyzed: evam bāhya pratītyasamutpādaḥ parikalpanā ātmakena anupacaya tvena draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Thus external dependent origination should be seen as having the nature of conceptualization and non-accumulation.

original: tathaivādhyātmikasyāpi hetuśca pratyayo dvidhā /🔽tathaivādhyātmikasyāpi bāhya pratītyasamutpādavad hetupratyayākāradvayopa nibandhanatvāt pṛthak dvividho'vagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā eva ādhyātmikasya api hetuḥ ca pratyayaḥ dvidhā  tathā eva ādhyātmikasya api bāhya pratītyasamutpāda vat hetu pratyaya ākāra dvaya upa nibandhana tvāt pṛthak dvividhaḥ avagantavyaḥ
translated: Similarly, the internal [dependent origination] also has two kinds of causes and conditions.🔽Just as external dependent origination is based on two kinds of causes and conditions, the internal [dependent origination] should also be understood as having two kinds separately.

original: dvidhā hetuścapratyaya iti tu ādhyātmikaḥ pratītyasamutpādo hetūpanibandhanaḥ pratyayopanibandhanaśca dvayākāro'vagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: dvidhā hetuḥ ca pratyayaḥ iti tu ādhyātmikaḥ pratītyasamutpādaḥ hetu upanibandhanaḥ pratyaya upanibandhanaḥ ca dvaya ākāraḥ avagantavyaḥ
translated: Causes and conditions are twofold, but internal dependent origination should be understood as having two aspects based on causes and conditions.

original: iṣṭa iti abhīṣṭasya ca abhipretasya abhimatasya cetyadhivacanam /
analyzed: iṣṭaḥ iti abhīṣṭasya ca abhipretasya abhimatasya ca iti adhivacanam

translated: How should the internal dependent origination's connection with causes be understood? It is said:

analyzed: ante maraṇa aṅga deśana tvāt mṛtyuḥ ante

original: yattayormadhye syāt tat tu madhya iṣyate /
analyzed: yat tayoḥ madhye syāt tat tu madhye iṣyate
translated: What is between them is considered to be the middle.

analyzed: tasmāt sūtre avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ  saṃskāra pratyayam vijñānam
translated: Therefore, in the sutra, it is said that the formations have ignorance as their condition.🔽Consciousness has formations as its condition.

analyzed: vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam

analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ṣaṣ āyatanam

analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśa pratyayā vedanā

analyzed: upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ

analyzed: bhava pratyayā jātiḥ

original: jātipratyayā jarāmaraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasyopāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: jāti pratyayāḥ jarā maraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti

The twelve links, consisting of birth, afflictions, and karma, are divided into three parts.

analyzed: tatra adhyātma pṛthivīdhātuḥ katamaḥ

analyzed: ātma dṛṣṭiḥ

original: ātmotkarṣaścetyetatkleśasaṃyutaṃ kliṣṭaṃ mana iti ekataḥ piṇḍīkṛtaṃ nāmarūpamityucyate /
analyzed: ātma utkarṣaḥ ca iti etat kleśa saṃyutam kliṣṭam manaḥ iti ekatas piṇḍīkṛtam nāma rūpam iti ucyate
translated: and self-pride. This defiled mind, united with these defilements, is combined into one mass and called name-and-form.

analyzed: dhātūnām sannipātāt vai śarīra utpādaḥ iṣyate
translated: The arising of the body is considered to be from the combination of the elements.

analyzed: anantara uditāḥ ṣaṭ dhātavaḥ
translated: The six elements just mentioned,

analyzed: sannipātāt vai iti tu vaikalya abhāvāt
translated: from the combination means from the absence of deficiency.

original: śarīramiti tu bhūta bhautika saṃnipāta piṇḍam /
analyzed: śarīram iti tu bhūta bhautika saṃnipāta piṇḍam
translated: Body means the mass of the elements and the derivatives of the elements.

analyzed: utpādaḥ nāma prādurbhāvaḥ
translated: Arising means appearance.

analyzed: iṣyate iti tu anumatam
translated: Is considered means is accepted.

original: asya kartrādi na vartate iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: asya kartṛ ādi na vartate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that its author and so on do not exist.

original: ātmātmīyavikalpānāmutpādastairna manyate /🔽iti tu asmābhirete utpāditā iti ca tairvayamutpāditā iti te'nyonya vikalpaṃ notpādayanti /
analyzed: ātma ātmīya vikalpānām utpādaḥ taiḥ na manyate  iti tu asmābhiḥ ete utpāditāḥ iti ca taiḥ vayam utpāditāḥ iti tena nyonya vikalpam na utpādayanti
translated: They do not conceive the arising of the distinctions of self and what belongs to self.🔽But we have produced them, and they have produced us - they do not produce mutual distinctions.

original: teṣu satsu samutpādaḥ teṣvasatsu na saṃbhavaḥ /🔽pratyayeṣu asatsu śarīrotpādo na yujyate /
analyzed: teṣu satsu samutpādaḥ teṣu asatsu na saṃbhavaḥ  pratyayeṣu asatsu śarīra utpādaḥ na yujyate
translated: Arising exists when they exist, non-arising is not possible when they do not exist.🔽The arising of the body is not possible when the conditions do not exist.

analyzed: yadā ādhyātmika pratyaya ādi vaikalya abhāvaḥ tadā saṃnipātāt śarīram utpadyate
translated: When there is no absence of deficiency in the internal conditions, then the body arises from the combination.

analyzed: vaikalye śarīram na utpādyate
translated: When there is deficiency, the body is not produced.

analyzed: na eva ātma ādi mayāḥ te hi nā api anyat ca api kiñcana
translated: They are not composed of self and so on, nor is there anything else at all.

original: tatra pṛthivīdhātustu nātmā ahaṃmameti manyanā viyuktatvāt /
analyzed: tatra pṛthivī dhātuḥ tu na ātmā aham mama iti manyanā viyukta tvāt
translated: Therein, the earth element is not the self, because it is devoid of the conception of I and mine.

analyzed: na sattva astu citta manaḥ vijñāna viyukta tvāt
translated: They are not beings, because they are devoid of mind, thought, and consciousness.

analyzed: na jīvaḥ calatva abhāvāt
translated: They are not living beings, because they do not move.

original: na jantustu janyajanaka virahitatvāt /🔽' na manujo' manuviyuktatvāt /
analyzed: na jantuḥ tu janya janaka virahita tvāt  na manu jaḥ manu viyukta tvāt
translated: They are not creatures, because they are devoid of what is produced and what produces.🔽They are not humans, because they are devoid of Manu.

analyzed: na mānavaḥ stu antar sthita mānava asadṛśa tvāt
translated: They are not human, because they do not resemble those who dwell within.

original: ' na strī' / na pumān na napuṃsakastu ādhyātmikastrī puruṣa napuṃsakātmakaḥ /
analyzed: na strī na pumān na napuṃsakaḥ tu ādhyātmika strī puruṣa napuṃsaka ātmakaḥ
translated: It is not a woman, not a man, not a neuter, because it is not composed of the inner woman, man, or neuter self.

original: na cāhaṃ mam iti tu ātmātmīya manyanā viyuktatvāt /
analyzed: na ca aham mam iti tu ātmātmīya manyanā viyukta tvāt
translated: And it is not I or mine, because it is free from the conception of self and what belongs to self.

original: nāpyanyaccāpi kiñcana iti tu īśvarādi kartṛ kriyā karma virahitatvāt /
analyzed: na api anyat ca api kiñcana iti tu īśvara ādi kartṛ kriyā karma virahita tvāt
translated: And it is also not anything else whatsoever, because it is free from an agent, action, and object such as a Lord.

analyzed: tadvat jalam
translated: The same applies to water.

analyzed: agniḥ vāyuḥ ākāśaḥ vijñāna dhātuḥ ca api na ātmā
translated: Fire, air, space, and the consciousness element are also not the self.

analyzed: na sattvaḥ
translated: It is not a sentient being.

analyzed: na jīvo  na jantuḥ  na manujaḥ
translated: It is not a living being.🔽It is not a creature.🔽It is not a human.

analyzed: na mānavaḥ
translated: It is not a man.

analyzed: na strī
translated: It is not a woman.

analyzed: na pumān
translated: It is not a man.

original: na napuṃsakam na cāhaṃ na mama syāt /
analyzed: na napuṃsakam na ca aham na mama syāt
translated: It is not a neuter. It is not I or mine.

original: na ceśvarādi anyat kiñcid iti jñātavyam /
analyzed: na ca īśvara ādi anyat kiñcid iti jñātavyam
translated: And it should be known that it is also not anything else whatsoever such as a Lord.

analyzed: yā eka piṇḍa ādi saṃjñā sā avidyā tri bhava chādikā
translated: That which is the conception of a single lump, etc., is ignorance, which covers the three realms of existence.

analyzed: tatra katamā avidyā ucyate
translated: What is that ignorance? It is said:

analyzed: tri bhava chādikā iti ucyate
translated: It is said to cover the three realms of existence.

analyzed: tri bhavaḥ tu bhava trayam kāma bhavaḥ
translated: The three realms of existence are the three realms of becoming: the realm of desire,

analyzed: rūpa bhavaḥ
translated: the realm of form,

analyzed: a rūpa bhavaḥ ca
translated: and the formless realm.

analyzed: te api sattva bhājana loke vyavahāreṇa dvividhāḥ vyavasthāpitāḥ
translated: They are also provisionally divided into two kinds: the world of sentient beings and the world of vessels.

original: atha ca dhātu gati yoni bhedena krama trayeṇa sthāpitaḥ /
analyzed: atha ca dhātu gati yoni bhedena krama trayeṇa sthāpitaḥ
translated: And they are established in three stages according to the distinction of realms, destinies, and birthplaces.

analyzed: katham iti ced
translated: If one asks how,

original: ucyate tatra kāmadhātuḥ ṣaṭtriṃśadāśrayanikāyavijñaptyavabhāsaṃ sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇa svabhāvena ekapiṇḍatvena kalpayan saṃjñayā grahaṇatvād avidyeti ucyate /
analyzed: ucyate tatra kāmadhātuḥ ṣaṭtriṃśat āśraya nikāya vijñapti avabhāsam sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa svabhāvena eka piṇḍa tvena kalpayan saṃjñayā grahaṇa tvāt avidyā iti ucyate
translated: It is said that there, the desire realm, conceiving the thirty-six bases as a single whole through the appearance of cognition, through the nature of the common and uncommon, is called ignorance because it is grasped by conceptualization.

analyzed: tatra ṣaṭtriṃśat āśraya nikāyāḥ tu aṣṭau uṣṇa svabhāvāḥ mahānarakāḥ
translated: There, the thirty-six bases are the eight great hells with a hot nature.

analyzed: śīta svabhāvāḥ aṣṭau mahānarakāḥ
translated: The eight great hells with a cold nature.

original: saṃjīva kālasūtra saṃghāta raurava mahāraurava tapana pratāpanāvīcayo 'ṣṭoṣṇanarakāḥ /
analyzed: saṃjīva kālasūtra saṃghāta raurava mahāraurava tapana pratāpana avīcayoḥ ṣṭa uṣṇa narakāḥ
translated: The eight hot hells are Saṃjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṃghāta, Raurava, Mahāraurava, Tapana, Pratāpana, and Avīci.

original: hāhādhara apapa aṭaṭa hāhāvat arbuda nirarbuda padma mahāpadma utpalāni śītasvabhāvatvād aṣṭau śītanarakāśca /
analyzed: hāhā dhara apapa aṭaṭa hāhāvat arbuda nirarbuda padma mahāpadma utpalāni śīta svabhāva tvāt aṣṭau śīta narakāḥ ca
translated: The eight cold hells are Hahava, Huhuva, Utpala, Padma, Mahāpadma, Arbuda, Nirarbuda, and Aṭaṭa, because they have a cold nature.

analyzed: pratyekaḥ prādeśikaḥ ca narakaḥ
translated: Each individual hell and the regional hells.
The basis of the pretas.

analyzed: tiryak āśrayaḥ
translated: The basis of the animals.

analyzed: asurāḥ āśrayaḥ
translated: The basis of the asuras.

analyzed: catur dvīpāḥ  aṣṭau antardvīpāḥ ca
translated: The four continents.🔽And the eight intermediate continents.

analyzed: tatra preta āśrayaḥ tu marau aṭavī kāntāre ca
translated: There, the basis of the pretas is in the desert and in the wilderness.

original: tadbhinnastu vibhāgaḥ grāma nagara nigama śmaśāna parvata aṭavī karvaṭa dvīpanadī vāyu sāgara palvala taḍāga kūpa udyānasthāna devālaya mātṛgṛha nāgaloka maru saras vṛkṣa śūnyālaya mahāpatha nadītaṭa araṇyavāsa prapāta setu kaulasthāna mukha mahāpatha āpaṇa catvara śrṛṅgāṭaka pāvanatīrthasthāna jalāśayādiṣu sthitvā svakarmavaśena vijñaptyavabhāsa vikalpodbhavānāṃ yadajñānaṃ seyamavidyā ityucyate /
analyzed: tad bhinnaḥ tu vibhāgaḥ grāma nagara nigama śmaśāna parvata aṭavī karvaṭa dvīpa nadī vāyu sāgara palvala taḍāga kūpa udyāna sthāna devālaya mātṛgṛha nāgaloka maru saras vṛkṣa śūnya ālaya mahāpatha nadī taṭa araṇyavāsa prapāta setu kaulasthāna mukha mahāpatha āpaṇa catvara śrṛṅgāṭaka pāvana tīrtha sthāna jalāśaya ādiṣu sthitvā sva karma vaśena vijñapti avabhāsa vikalpa udbhavānām yat ajñānam sā iyam avidyā iti ucyate
translated: The division different from that is as follows: in villages, towns, markets, cremation grounds, mountains, forests, forts, islands, rivers, air, oceans, ponds, lakes, wells, gardens, temples, women's quarters, nāga worlds, deserts, lakes, trees, empty houses, highways, river banks, forest dwellings, precipices, bridges, family places, mouths, highways, shops, crossroads, intersections, sacred bathing places, water reservoirs, and so on, abiding by the power of one's own karma, the ignorance of the arising of the appearances of communication and conceptualization is called this ignorance.

analyzed: tiryaksthānam madhye sāgaram  yoni sthānāni catvāri
translated: The place of animals is in the middle of the ocean.🔽The four places of birth are: born from eggs,

analyzed: jarāyu jaḥ  saṃsveda jaḥ
translated: born from wombs,🔽born from moisture,

analyzed: upapādukaḥ ca
translated: and spontaneously born.

analyzed: yoni āśraya bhedena vividhā tiryagjagat vijñapti avabhāsita vikalpa vāsanā lipta santānāḥ
translated: The various animal worlds, with their continuums smeared by the latent tendencies of communication and conceptualization, are due to the differences in the bases of the wombs.

original: tadanyathāvibhaktāḥ gardabha sūkara vānara gaja uṣṭra aśva mṛga mahiṣa gaugavaya camarī śva śrṛgāla nakula mūṣaka siṃha vyāghra tarakṣu ṛkṣa vṛka mārjāra mīna kacchapa makara śiśumāra sarpa pipīlikā lūtā pataṃga tittiri pipīlaka kṛmi valmīka godhā kīṭa jalavāsi śuka śārikā kokilā mayūra haṃsa krauñca vaka kāka gṛdhra ullūka jīvañjīva suparṇādayo'niścita gatitvāt svakarmavāsanā pāratantryeṇa avabhāsākāraṃ sthitaṃ tu yadajñānaṃ tadapi avidyā ityucyate /
analyzed: tad anyathā vibhaktāḥ gardabha sūkara vānara gaja uṣṭra aśva mṛga mahiṣa gaugavaya camarī śva śrṛgāla nakula mūṣaka siṃha vyāghra tarakṣu ṛkṣa vṛka mārjāra mīna kacchapa makara śiśumāra sarpa pipīlikā lūtā pataṃga tittiri pipīlaka kṛmi valmīka godhā kīṭa jalavāsi śuka śārikā kokilā mayūra haṃsa krauñca vaka kāka gṛdhra ullūka jīvañjīva suparṇa ādayaḥ niścita gati tvāt sva karma vāsanā pāratantryeṇa
translated: Those who are otherwise divided, such as donkeys, pigs, monkeys, elephants, camels, horses, deer, buffaloes, cows, oxen, camels, dogs, jackals, mongooses, mice, lions, tigers, hyenas, bears, wolves, cats, fish, tortoises, crocodiles, alligators, snakes, ants, spiders, moths, partridges, worms, anthills, lizards, insects, aquatic creatures, parrots, mynas, cuckoos, peacocks, geese, cranes, herons, crows, vultures, owls, jīvañjīva, Suparṇa, etc., due to their uncertain course, that ignorance which exists in the form of appearance through dependence on the latent tendencies of their own karma, that too is called ignorance.

analyzed: asurāṇām catur āśrayaḥ tu sumeroḥ catuḥ pariṣaṇḍa madhye asti
translated: And the abode of the asuras is in the middle of the four terraces of Mount Meru.

original: tadbhinnavibhāgena sthitaṃ parvata aṭavī vana udyāna nadī grāmādiṣu svakarma vaśāt prajñaptāvabhāsa vikalpanodbhūtamanyasthānānāṃ yadajñānaṃ tadapi avidyetyucyate /
analyzed: tad bhinna vibhāgena sthitam parvata aṭavī vana udyāna nadī grāma ādiṣu sva karma vaśāt prajñapta avabhāsa vikalpana udbhūtam anya sthānānām yat ajñānam tat api avidyā iti ucyate
translated: That ignorance which arises in other places through the conceptualization of designation due to the power of their own karma, existing in the division different from that, in mountains, forests, gardens, rivers, villages, etc., that too is called ignorance.

original: naraka sattvānāṃ svakarmavaśitānukūlavikalpanodbhavānāṃ tu anavataptamahāsāgarād viṃśatisāhasrayojanādhobhājanasya vijñapti svabhāvamūlabhūteṣu anyasthāneṣvabhi nirvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: naraka sattvānām sva karma vaśitā anukūla vikalpana udbhavānām tu anavatapta mahā sāgarāt viṃśati sāhasra yojana adhas bhājanasya svabhāva mūla bhūteṣu anya sthāneṣu abhi nirvṛttiḥ
translated: But for the beings in hell, born from the transformation of consciousness in accordance with their own karma, the receptacle world is manifested in other places, which are the root of the nature of consciousness, below the great ocean of Unheated, twenty thousand yojanas down.

original: tato'nyatra pratyekasattvasya narakādi bhājanasya vijñapti vikalpanodbhūtasya parvata aṭavī maru darī prapāta nadī tīrādisthānābhinirvṛttaṃ yadajñānamidamapya vidyetyucyate /
analyzed: tatas nyatra pratyeka sattvasya naraka ādi bhājanasya vijñapti vikalpanā udbhūtasya parvata aṭavī maru darī prapāta nadī tīra ādi sthāna abhinirvṛttam yat ajñānam idam api a vidyā iti ucyate
translated: Apart from that, the individual being's hell and other receptacle worlds, born from the transformation of consciousness, are manifested in places such as mountains, forests, deserts, caves, precipices, river banks, etc. This ignorance is also called avidyā.

analyzed: catvāraḥ dvīpāḥ tu pūrvasyām videhaḥ
translated: There are four continents: in the east, Videha;

analyzed: dakṣiṇasyām jambūdvīpaḥ  paścimāyām aparagodānīyaḥ

translated: There are eight intermediate continents: in the east of Videha, Pūrvavideha and Videha;

analyzed: prabhedena kāreṇa bhinnāḥ

original: svavijñānāvabhāsavikalpanāvaśenodbhūtaṃ vibhinnaprapaṃca vāsanāliptaṃ tādṛśaṃ yadajñānam idamapi avidyetyucyate /
analyzed: sva vijñāna avabhāsa vikalpanā vaśena udbhūtam vibhinna prapaṃca vāsanā liptam tādṛśam yat ajñānam idam api avidyā iti ucyate
translated: The ignorance that arises by the power of the conception of a manifold world, tainted by latent tendencies, which is the appearance of one's own cognition, is also called ignorance.

analyzed: ṣaṣ devānām sattva bhājana avabhāsa vijñapti avabhāsa viśeṣa sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa aśeṣa svabhāveṣu piṇḍa grahaṇa kalpanā vaśena udbhūtam yat ajñānam idam api avidyā iti ucyate
translated: The ignorance that arises by the power of the conception of grasping a whole in the six gods, in the distinction of the appearance of beings and vessels, in the appearance of cognition, in the general and particular, and in the entirety of one's own nature, is also called ignorance.

analyzed: tatra ṣaṭ devanikāyāḥ iti
translated: There, the six classes of gods are:

analyzed: sva karma vaśena

analyzed: evam pṛthak gati yoni bahu tva bhedena vibhinna sattva bhājana lokāḥ iti ākhyātāḥ sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa viśeṣa ādi piṇḍa graha udbhūtaḥ ekatas saṃkṣipya kāmadhātuḥ iti ucyate
translated: Thus, the worlds of beings and inanimate objects are differentiated by the many different types of individual births and wombs. They are called the desire realm when condensed into one category, arising from the grasping of the mass of general and specific characteristics.
